awd_titl_txt: Structural role of 5-hydroxymethylcytosine in promoting recombination
awd_abstract_narration:
Proposal Title: Structural role of 5-hydroxymethylcytosine in promoting recombination

It is well recognized that the linear arrangement of C, G, A, and T of DNA defines the genetic code of a cell. We also now recognize that, beyond this linear sequence, modifications to the DNA bases can also be transferred from the parent to affect how this code is interpreted in daughter cells; this is the epigenetic code. Methylation is a well-studied epigenetic marker, but the oxidation of methyl groups on cytosine, to form hydroxymethylcytosine (5hmC) constitutes a less common, but no less important epigenetic marker. This project aims to determine how 5hmC affects the three-dimensional structure of DNA at the atomic level, to affect recombination,
The process by which genetic information is transferred between chromosomes in eukaryotic cells (including human cells), between a virus and its host, and to repair damaged DNAs. The results from this project will have significant impact on our understanding of epigenetic markers and their biological functions. The potential economic impact is that this understanding will allow the design of new technologies to introduce genes into biological systems by promoting more efficient mechanisms for recombination.  The project will, in addition, impact the science literacy and the training of high school students in the STEM areas by bringing hands-on experiences to the classroom of local high schools and bringing high school students onto the Colorado State University campus. A diverse cadre of graduate students will also  be trained in a STEM field.  

5-Hydroxymethylcytosine (5hmC) has recently seen renewed interests as the "6th" base of the genome. The function of 5hmC has generally been recognized as being an intermediate in the demethylation of 5-methylcytosine; however, recent mapping of 5hmC occurrence across genomes suggests that the modified base serves as an epigenetic marker and affects transcription in a tissue dependent manner. In addition, evidence suggests that 5hmC promotes recombination in vitro and in vivo, through a pathway dependent on the general nucleotide cutting enzyme endonuclease G (EndoG). The project will test the hypothesis that 5hmC plays a structural role by stabilizing a recombination intermediate (the four stranded DNA Holliday junction), which can provide specificity to EndoG, even though the enzyme does not appear to discriminate between 5hmC-modified and unmodified DNAs. The goal of this project is to test a model that 5hmC stabilizes Holliday junctions in inverted repeat sequences, thereby providing a stable intermediate for EndoG to bind and cut. The aims to achieve this goal are: Aim 1) crystallographic and calorimetric studies to determine the effects of 5hmC-modification on the structure and thermodynamic stability of DNA Holliday junctions; Aim 2) biochemical studies to determine the structural context and mechanism by which EndoG recognizes 5hmC-modifications in DNA; and Aim 3) biochemical studies to determine whether 5hmC-modifications pauses the junction to allow site specific cutting by EndoG.

por.por_cntn:
The outcome in the intellectual merit of this project was to demonstrate the effect of 5-hydroxylmethylcytosine (5hmC) modifications on the structure of DNA and how a recombination specific protein recognizes this modified base. 5hmC is now recognized as an epigenetic marker in mammals. This project initiated with a finding that 5hmC promoted recombination in mice, and the identification of an enzyme (endonuclease G, or EndoG) as the enzyme primarily responsible for the recognition of 5hmC and the two-fold increase the recombination. The original hypothesis of the project was that 5hmC helps to stabilize the DNA Holliday junction (four-stranded structural intermediate in recombination), which pauses the migration of the junction, and that EndoG is a junction recognition enzyme that selectively binds to 5hmC modified junctions. During this project, we determined the crystal structures of a DNA junction with 5hmC and of mouse EndoG with and without DNA. The structure of the 5hmC modified junction along with calorimetric studies to determine the effect of the modification on the stability of the DNA supported the hypothesis that 5hmC is structurally accommodated by and enthapically stabilizes the four-stranded DNA. The structure of EndoG along with a series of biochemical studies indicated that the enzyme is a 5hmC/junction specific enzyme, possibly functioning as a resolvase that helps initiate repair of damaged DNA.

 

Binding studies showed that the inactive enzyme binds junctions with a dissociation constant (KD) of ~75 nM, and duplex or single-stranded DNAs with KDs > 75 µM (1000-fold higher affinity for junction over other forms of DNA). 5hmC modifications, however, did not significantly affect the affinity for junction or duplex DNAs. The effect of the modification was seen to increase the cleavage of the DNA junction by ~10-fold, but had no effect on duplex cutting (in fact, the enzyme has very low activity on duplexes, whether modified or not). The primary cleavage product of the junction was seen to be double-stranded DNA, which is consistent with a resolvase.

 

The structure of the mouse enzyme showed an unwinding of an alpha-helix in the active site that is seen in the structures of the invertebrate homologs, which do not recognize 5hmC or promote recombination at such sites. This unwinding places a conserved Cys side chain into the DNA binding site, whereas this same amino acid is extended into solvent in the invertebrate enzyme. We show that replacing this Cys with Ala in the mouse EndoG eliminates the 5hmC effects of cutting efficiency, but not on junction DNA binding. The structure of the inactive enzyme did not show DNA in the active site (because it is blocked by crystal lattice interactions, but to another site that is orthogonal to the active site. We suggest that this second site is responsible for the junction recognition, providing a site to bind a second arm of the four-armed DNA. This second binding surface is not conserved in the structures of the invertebrate homologs. The broader impacts of the research is that we have found molecular evidence to support the 5hmC/junction specificity for mouse EndoG that is not present in the invertebrate enzyme, with a mechanism for 5hmC recognition that does not require base flipping, as with other such enzymes.

 

The broader impacts on the scientific workforce is that the project trained two PhD graduate students, one of which graduated and has accepted a faculty position at the University of Colorado at Colorado Springs while the other continues pursuing this project, and a technician, who has now accepted a position at the Texas Advanced Computing Center. In addition, the PI was the lead co-organizer of a summer Workshop on Alternative Careers for Graduate Students, that provided graduate students and postdocs with information on how to and networking opportunities to pursue career paths that differ from the standard academic track. The event included 15 speakers from biotechnology, industry, start-ups, law, government, and other careers, and drew an audience of over 75 from across the Colorado State University campus. Finally the PI has created a new Professional Masters program in Biological Data Analytics, which will initiate in Fall 2019.
